Deeply v-cut letters with minimal serifs and somewhat uneven in both height and width. Small triangular interpuncts throughout. C, O, G consistently large/wide. P is open, R is closed. E has equal bars.

Three lines of Latin text (despite abrasions, it is likely that there are no missing lines), seemingly set in the middle of the face of the base. Use of one triangular interpunct (line 2).
Text is very deeply and widely incised. Text is regular, with serifs. Spacing between letters and lines is precise.
Likely an early colonist of Thermae Himeraeae, probably Augustan in date (after 21 BCE).

A single line of monumental letters set neatly in the vertical middle of the available field.

The letters are deeply square cut (7-12 mm deep, typically 8-10), without serifs, for the insertion of bronze letters, with triangular interpuncts and use of supraline on numeral. Bronze is preserved in the three interpuncts in fragment A, and the letter N in fragment A preserves some of the fixing material for the original bronze letter. Note that the I of 'vir' is extended, 138mm tall.

Three lines of fragmentary Latin text (a fourth line is possible, but the break obscures this; the epigraphic formula suggests three lines only). There is a large vacat on the left side of all text.

The text is irregularly and shakily carved. Letter height and width differ even on the same line, and the T on line 2 is significantly taller than other letters. Simple serifs used. The vertical bar for the 'R' in line 2 is bisected by a long horizontal foot. At the end of line 2, the top of a serifed downstroke is just visible after the T.

Three line Latin inscription in top half of stone. Text complete. Text almost centred, but shifted slightly to the right. Grey discolouration around letters.

Letters are tall, thin, and well defined, in pronounced v-cut. Characters in line 1 differ from those on the following two lines (compare A and N). Defined serifs on all letters. Use of triangular interpuncts on lines two and three. First line is more deeply cut than the other two. End of line 2 tapers upwards, to fit into stone. Every instance of 'X' have deeply and widely incised lines that slope from left to right.

Three lines of Latin text maintaining a consistent left margin with initial interpuncts, and irregular right margin. Mixture of different shaped hederae and interpuncts. Most interpuncts are diamond or triangle shaped.

Letters are generally even, tall and well-formed, although not all letters fall on the line in line 2, and the 'S' at the end of line 2 is some distance from the preceeding letter. The top right stem of the first 'X' in line three is curved to the right, and follows the curve of the following hedera. Mason has put 'XV' in ligature in line 3, potentially to save space at the end of the line.

Three lines of Latin text, centred on stone. Interpuncts are all slightly different from each other, but shaped (roughly) like horizontal commas, and notably placed at line beginnings and ends as well as between words. Although Bivona (1994) claims that there are traces of guidelines, these are not visible upon autopsy.
Most letters have a broad fairly square module and are regular, with simple straight line serifs. Text is rendered in straight lines. Incision of letters is not particularly deep.

Funerary inscription for the slave Ianuarius

Three lines of Latin text, with a gap to the left of the text (but not on the right). Clearly inscribed horizontal guidelines to top and bottom of each line, with an incised left and right margin also. Guidelines have the following heights: line 1 (39 mm), line 2 (37 mm), line 3 (35mm). The spaces between the guidelines are not equal, between lines 1 and 2 is a space of between 4-8mm (the gap reduces to the right), and between lines 2 and 3 is a space of between 5-6mm (again reducing at the right). Use of interpuncts consistently between words.

Text is very elegantly carved, following the guidelines with some freedom. Text is has a consistent left margin, not quite perfectly judged in length to the right margin, with some compression at line end. Elegant use of serifs. Interpuncts predominantly of a 'comma' shape. Vs have a particularly distinctive shape, with greater slope on left line. Size of letters decreases from left to right, as the stone-cutter runs out of room. Diminuitive 'o' at the end of line 3.
37-41 (final 'o' at the end of the line is 18mm)

The first line is set to the left, with lines 2 and 3 indented by 1.5 letter spaces. The text reduces in size in line 3, and the gap visible below line 3 (up to 32 mm)  is greater than the normal interlineation. Guidelines are visible in lines 2-3, but the letters do not appear to follow them.

116 CE if Manganaro's restoration is accepted, but the potential attributions range through to the following century

Four lines of ancient Greek filling the upper portion of the face of the stone, with a consistent left margin, the right side more cramped and irregular. The lower part of the stone is blank.

Letters are somewhat irregular in size, with simple straight line serifs terminating most strokes. Alpha with both broken bar and straight bar; beta both open and closed with rounded eyes; epsilon quadrate with equal length strokes; theta and omicron are rhomboid; kappa has short arms; mu has vertical first and last, short middle strokes; pi has overhanging horizontal; sigma is quadrate lunate; omega is inverted cursive form, having the appearance of mu; the pi-rho ligature is used twice; staurogram at the end of the text.

The municipium of the Haluntini honours Gnaeus Pollienus
The text occupies five lines over the upper part of the front face.

Regular letters with a fairly square module, simply engraved without serifs. Alpha has broken bar; Kappa has full length arms; Mu has vertical first and last, with mid-strokes only descending half-way; omicron is full size; Pi has full length verticals, and slightly overlapping horizontal bar; omega is slightly open and nearly circular, with horizontal tails/feet.

The use of the term 'municipium' in Greek places this text almost certainly after the grant of Latin rights to Sicily by Julius Caesar (probably 46 BCE), but equally the use of Greek implies a date not later than the early Augustan period. The lettering is compatible with a late Hellenistic date.

Two lines of Greek letters filling the width of the surviving stone

Crude and irregular letters of unequal size, deeply incised. Omicron is small and mid-line; kappa has short equal length arms attached to the vertical; epsilon has shorter middle bar (i the first instance detached from the vertical); alpha has straight bar; rho has rounded closed eye.

1Δίοκλε
2χαῖρε
Five lines of Greek letters, centred on the stone

Slightly crudely incised simple broad letters without serifs. Nu i sregular; epsilon has slightly shorter middle bar; mu has slightly inward leaning first and last strokes, the mid-strokes reach down to the base-line; rho has a small eye, not always fully closed; alpha has broken bar; omega varies between open circle closed by horizontal bar and closed ovoid form with horizontal bar; phi has a small circular eye; sigma has standard form with horizontal top and bottom storkes; omicron is approximately the same size as other letters.

Two lines of Greek letters, across the middle of the front face. The letters are aligned on the left margin, and are arranged in pseudo-stoichedon, i.e. vertically aligned.

Letters of the early Hellenistic or late classical period. Phi has an elliptical eye; alpha has straight bar; omicron is almost full size; sigma has widely diverging top and bottom strokes; theta is smaller than other letters, with a dot in the middle; omega is open; mu has diverging first and last strokes, and the mid-point only descends half-way; epsilon has short middle stroke. Words are separated on both lines by a three vertical points.

Later 4th or 3rd century BCE on the basis of the letter forms

Latin text, aligned to the left margin over two lines, with guidelines (no interlinear spacing)

Somewhat irregularly spaced tall letters, with thin strokes but pronounced terminations to the strokes.  A has a detached downward descending middle-bar; E is tall thin, with shorter top bar; G is formed as a C with the tail a second short curving stroke; P is closed; R has small eye, slightly open; S leans forward slightly. The use of interpuncts is erractic and seemingly not linked to sense, with a triangular punct after the initial A and at the end of line 2; a large reversed comma-shape midline after the R of line 1; and a smaller comma-shape mid-line between V and R in line 2.

Somewhat irregular deep-cut letters with pronounced terminations and occasionally extravagant serifs/flourishes (e.g. on X or E), and a varying tendency to the later narrow elongated style (e.g. TFL in line 5), and M sometimes with the upper strokes extended well above the join. A consistently lacks a cross-bar; E generally has equal length strokes, but with the top stroke often extended upwards; F, tall, narrow, and upward pointing; M sometimes with extended apices, sometimes without (all four strokes full length); P is closed; R sometimes open, with extended tail; X frequently over extended upper right. No interpuncts.

Fragment of a bilingual dedication to Priapus

Five lines of regularly spaced Greek letters followed by three lines of Latin letters. The first two lines of Latin text follow the same spacing as the Greek text; the final line is seemingly centered, more widely spaced (with interpuncts) and separated by a slightly greater interval from the lines above. Although the top of the stone is damaged, the visible space above line 1 is greater than that between the following lines.

Regular, well-cut Greek letters with clearly defined serifs at the end of strokes: Omicron, omega and theta all have rhomboid form; in some instances this is actually a pentagonal form, flat across the top; Omega is open at the bottom; Sigma is four bar and regular; Epsilon has equal horizontal strokes; Alpha has broken bar; the diagonal of the Nu starts and finishes well below/above the ends of the vertical strokes. The Latin letters show the beginnings of the move towards cursive forms: M has extended upper strokes and the midpoint reaches to the bottom of the line; A also has extended upper stroke and lacks a cross-bar; O is rounded, in contrast to the Greek text, as is Q with extended tail; P is open; R is closed; E has short upward slanting strokes; L has a long foot, forming almost a C.
Scan of photo in NSA 1922 p.494 fig.2
Manganaro, 1977, Per la storia dei culti nella Sicilia greca
Ribezzo, 1925, Sulla dedica bilingue del Priapo bifronte di Aci-Catania

Small altar of Zeus Soter Hieron
Two lines of Greek text in the field on the front face of the altar (8.5 cm wide x 2.5 cm high)

The first three letters are more deeply engraved, the remaining letters are little more than scratched in the surface with a sharp point, and are increasingly irregular in form. Omega is open; top and bottom bars of sigma tending slightly apart; omicron is small than other letters; epsilon has horizontals of equal length.

Remains of four lines of Greek text, of which the preserved traces suggest that lines 1-3 filled the width of the stone, but line 4 is more widely spaced and has a vacat at the right, and below.

Regular widely spaced, finely incised letters, of consistent height throughout. Letters have basic triangular terminations to the strokes. Alpha is broken-bar; epsilon has short middle stroke (whether detached or not is unclear); kappa has equal length short arms; sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes, with the middle strokes extending half-width.
The letter forms would suggest later third or more likely second century BCE
Manganaro, 1961, Ricerche di epigrafia siceliota. I. Per la storia del culto delle divinita orientali in Sicilia
Sfameni Gasparro, 1973, I culti orientali in Sicilia
Vidman, 1969, Sylloge inscriptionum religionis Isiacae et Sarapiacae

Four lines of Greek letters; the text appears to be centred on the stone, with slight vacat below.

. Based upon the single published photograph: regularly and neatly carved fine lettters without serfis or significant terminations. Alpha has straight bar; Mu has vertical first and last, with midstrokes descending halfway; omicron is small and mid-line; sigma has diverging top and bottom strokes, the mid-strokes meeting at half width; omega is nearly full height, slightly ovoid, open with short horizontal tails. No editor records the size of the letters.
4th century or 3rd century BCE based on the letters.

Greek text over four lines, centred in the main panel of the
                                        tabula ansata on the front face of the urn.

Neat and regular square letters. Phi and omicron are rhomboid in
                                    form; standard four-bar sigma; epsilon has horizontal bars of equal length; alpha
                                    has a slightly extended apex; mu has extended apices, and all four strokes are full
                                    length and off-vertical. There is one instance of ligature in line 3, and
                                    interpuncts are in the form of simple triangular incisions.
69 CE — first half of 2nd century CE

Funerary inscription for Xenokritos son of Hephaistokles, of Massalia

Three lines of Greek text engraved across the full width of the front face. The
                                        third line is slightly smaller than the first two. There is damage to the left
                                        margin of all three lines, and across the lower edge of the third line. The face
                                        is weathered and the letters are faint, especially at the end of the second
                                        line.

Very regularly and elegantly engraved letters without serifs, wide forms, evenly
                                    spaced. Sigma has diverging top and bottom bars; epsilon short middle bar; omicron
                                    perfectly round, smaller then the other letters (c.21 mm) and mid-line; omega is
                                    round, smaller than other letters, and open at the bottom; alpha has straight bar;
                                    kappa has full-length legs; phi has a elliptical eye. The letters are very similar
                                    to those of dated Hieronian inscriptions, i.e. third century BC.
Manganaro, 1992, Massalioti per il Mediterraneo: tra Spagna, Sardegna e Sicilia
Prag, 2017, Un unpublished funerary inscription with bichrome painted relief lettering from Hellenistic Syracuse (I.Sicily 3387)

The text extends across the full surviving width of the middle band of the front face.

Slightly unevenly spaced deeply v-cut letters. Delta has a slight apex; Mu has vertical first and last, middle strokes only descend half-way; Nu has lower right angle slightly above the line; omicron is full size; rhos has small closed, curved eye; sigma has prallel top and bottom strokes, with relatively shallow mid-strokes; phi has large rhomboid body, traversed by the vertical which is extended (120 mm); omega is open, rounded, with long horizontal tails, and is slightly smaller than the full line-height (75-85 mm).

(Following Orsi's apograph in his taccuino) Small regular neat letters with terminations to the strokes but no signficant serifs. Alpha has straight bar; Epislon has slightly shortened middle bar; Zeta is vertical with wide top and bottom horizontal strokes; Kappa has slightly shortened arms; Mu has vertical first and last, with the middle strokes almost reaching to the base line; omicron is full-size; Sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes; Omega is round full-sized, and almost closed.
2nd or 1st century BCE by the lettering which is later Hellenistic

Five lines of Greek text, centred on the stone, with a consistent left margin, and final line (numerals) centred between ivy leaves.

Letters are deeply v-cut, somewhat elongated, and showing some tendency towards curvature in e.g. the M. Minial use of serifs. Lunate omega, but rectilinear epsilon and sigma. Alpha with broken bar; mu with four full-length, slanting strokes; kappa with short ams; omicron ovoid but full height; epsilon tall and thin, all bars of equal length; zeta an equal length Z. Use of interpunct to mark off the names, and hedera around the numeral.
Photo J. Prag, 2014-09-10, by permission of Museo Archeologico Regionale Paolo Orsi

Remains of three lines of text, of which only the middle line is preserved to full height. Text is laid out between double guidelines.

Relatively tall and thin letters, but still of regular square form, of somewhat irregular width, with short basic serifs at the end of strokes; somewhat roughly chiselled. R has an extended tail which does not reach to the lower line; O is tall and narrow; E has slightly shorter middle stroke. M is narrow, with very short middle strokes that join at the midpoint and join  the verticals well below the top.

Text is approximately centred on the stone, with a consistent left margin for lines 2-5, lines 1 and 6 centred.

Simply cut letters without notable serifs. Interpuncts are used but not consistently. Alpha has straight bar; epsilon is rectilinear with equal length bars; zeta is a plain Z; theta is rhomboid with detached cross-bar; kappa has slightly shortened arms; omicron is rhomboid; rho has closed round loop; sigma is rectilinear with horizontal bars; omega is rhomboid and open.

Five lines of Greek letters, with line 1 centred, lines 2-5 with a regular left margin.

Simply and neatly cut letters with almost no serifs, well-spaced horizontally, but with minimal interlinear spacing. Simple interpuncts used frequently but inconsistently. Alpha has broken bar; epsilon is rectilinear with equal length bars; zeta is simple Z; theta is rhomboid with detached cross-bar; kappa has slightly shortened arms; omicron is rhomboid; rho has small closed and rounded eye; sigma is rectilinear with horizontal top and bottom strokes.
